sentences: Norman Joseph Bédard (born July 30, 1962), also known by the former stage names Norman Iceberg and Norman Joseph, is a Canadian singer-songwriter.
Early years:
section: == Early years: Performing as Norman Iceberg ==

sentences: A graphic artist turned performance artist, Norman Bedard emerged from the Montreal underground music scene in the early '80s under the name Norman Iceberg.
section: == Early years: Performing as Norman Iceberg ==

sentences: One of a handful of gender-bending new wave artists to come out following the success of artists like Duran Duran, Boy George and Gary Numan, Bedard was recruited by music producer Tony Green, responsible for France Joli’s 1979 disco hit "Come To Me".
section: == Early years: Performing as Norman Iceberg ==

sentences: Norman Bedard's experimental, minimal electro sound was therefore remodeled to cater to the dance club scene as evident on his debut, Be My Human Tonight (RCA).
section: == Early years: Performing as Norman Iceberg ==

sentences: Person(a), released in 1987, was a conceptual collection of synthpop songs reflecting a young man’s own vision of life, and featuring keyboardists such as Lenny Pinkas (Men Without Hats), Mario Spezza (Rational Youth) and Mic Lussier.
section: == Early years: Performing as Norman Iceberg ==

sentences: The cover photograph of him posing nude - pre-dating Prince’s Lovesexy by several months - stirred up controversy.
section: == Early years: Performing as Norman Iceberg ==

sentences: 1988 saw the release of Gotta Move.
section: == Early years: Performing as Norman Iceberg ==

sentences: With its frenetic, energetic beat, 1989’s "Kiss the Beauty" was a favourite for months in night clubs.
section: == Early years: Performing as Norman Iceberg ==

sentences: With its frenetic, energetic beat, 1989’s "Kiss the Beauty" was a favourite for months in night clubs.
section: == Early years: Performing as Norman Iceberg ==

sentences: With its frenetic, energetic beat, 1989’s "Kiss the Beauty" was a favourite for months in night clubs.
section: == Early years: Performing as Norman Iceberg ==

sentences: A couple of years later, "We Act" got him a “Best Video” nomination at the Musique Plus (his native Quebec equivalent to MTV) Video Awards.
section: == Early years: Performing as Norman Iceberg ==

sentences: In the early '90s, American music industry executives strongly advised him to change his name in order to avoid any confusion with new rap artists Ice-T, Ice Cube and Vanilla Ice.
section: == Transition: From Norman Iceberg to Norman Bedard ==

sentences: However, with a strong gay following, Bedard decided to keep using his stage name, performing notably at the 1992 Los Angeles Gay Pride, the notorious Whisky A Go-Go, as well as Prince’s Glam Slam, backed by dancers Viktor Manoel (from David Bowie’s 'Glass Spider' tour), Luca Tommassini and Carrie Ann Inaba (from Madonna’s 'Girlie Show' tour).
section: == Transition: From Norman Iceberg to Norman Bedard ==

sentences: Ending a series of concerts with a five-piece rock band at The Roxy Theatre in Los Angeles, Bedard’s actual last appearance under the name Norman Iceberg was on the syndicated TV show Sheena Metal's Freakin' Rock Review in 1993.
section: == Transition: From Norman Iceberg to Norman Bedard ==

sentences: He also recorded as Norman Joseph in 1994 before deciding to go back to using Norman Bedard, his last birth name.
section: == Transition: From Norman Iceberg to Norman Bedard ==

sentences: Committed to his craft, and now on his own, Norman Bedard continued writing songs, working with collaborators such as Kevin Komoda (Rational Youth, Sarah McLachlan), and self-produced several pre-prod albums not available commercially, which revealed a more subdued side.
section: == Transition: From Norman Iceberg to Norman Bedard ==

sentences: In November 2007, Norman announced via his website that a brand new album scheduled for release in 2008 was in the works.
section: == Transition: From Norman Iceberg to Norman Bedard ==

sentences: In November 2007, Norman announced via his website that a brand new album scheduled for release in 2008 was in the works.
section: == Transition: From Norman Iceberg to Norman Bedard ==

sentences: The album was confirmed to be titled Vital on March 9, 2009, with a release date set for Spring 2009.
section: == Transition: From Norman Iceberg to Norman Bedard ==

sentences: The album was confirmed to be titled Vital on March 9, 2009, with a release date set for Spring 2009.
section: == Transition: From Norman Iceberg to Norman Bedard ==

sentences: Vital, and a remastered version of We Act were both released simultaneously on July 15, 2009.
section: == Transition: From Norman Iceberg to Norman Bedard ==

sentences: "Wonderful" was the first single from Vital, released on March 2, 2010.
section: == Transition: From Norman Iceberg to Norman Bedard ==

sentences: Also released on the same date was Norman Iceberg's "Crawl" (Alternate Version), originally recorded in the 1990s at Men Without Hats’ home studio.
section: == Transition: From Norman Iceberg to Norman Bedard ==

sentences: On June 1, 2010, Bedard released the second single from his Vital album, "A Day With My Self", described by Richard Morris of Pink Paper as a "folky ditty".
section: == Transition: From Norman Iceberg to Norman Bedard ==

sentences: On June 1, 2010, Bedard released the second single from his Vital album, "A Day With My Self", described by Richard Morris of Pink Paper as a "folky ditty".
section: == Transition: From Norman Iceberg to Norman Bedard ==

sentences: It was followed with the release of Norman Iceberg's 1+1=2, also recorded in the 1990s at Men Without Hats’ home studio and newly remastered in 2010.
section: == Transition: From Norman Iceberg to Norman Bedard ==

sentences: It was followed with the release of Norman Iceberg's 1+1=2, also recorded in the 1990s at Men Without Hats’ home studio and newly remastered in 2010.
section: == Transition: From Norman Iceberg to Norman Bedard ==

sentences: The following single, "Thank You", was released on October 4, 2010.
section: == Transition: From Norman Iceberg to Norman Bedard ==

sentences: Norman's next single "Space" was released on February 8, 2011.
